He looked up from his desk, the scattered papers suddenly forming a terrifying picture. “Sir,” he interrupted, his voice tight. “Von Hessler’s secret project… Is he building ships, too?” Finch stopped, and his silence was the most terrifying answer of all. A new kind of war was brewing in the shadows.

The sound of her mother’s work was the soundtrack to Alie’s life: the rhythmic rasp of a hand plane, the buzz of the table saw, the decisive thud of a mallet. Their garage was a place of creation, turning raw lumber into chairs, tables, and cabinets. It was a comforting, productive noise. But from the house next door, Mr. Gable’s house, there was only silence. A deep, unsettling quiet. The only evidence of his existence was the weekly appearance of a new ship-in-a-bottle on his front windowsill. Each one was more intricate than the last, with microscopic rigging and perfectly painted sails, a fleet of impossibly trapped vessels. Alie sat on the porch steps, watching her mother sand a smooth curve onto a tabletop. She glanced at the dark window next door, where a tiny, perfect galleon had appeared that morning. A strange, cold thought connected the two workshops—one so open and loud, the other so secretive and silent. “Is he building ships, too?” Alie asked. Her mother’s hands stilled. She didn’t look at Alie, but at Mr. Gable’s house, her friendly face clouded with a deep, unspoken worry.

Grandpa smelled of pipe tobacco and wintergreen. He sat on the edge of Alie’s bed, his old Sky-Sailor’s coat draped over the chair. “The best clouds for sailing,” he rasped, pointing a wrinkled finger out the window, “are the cumulonimbus. They’re full of lightning and ambition, but if you can harness one, it’ll take you all the way to the dawn.” He spoke of his old vessel, the *Stardust Drifter*, woven from solidified moonlight and powered by bottled winds. He showed her his compass, its needle pointing not north, but straight at Polaris. Alie listened, captivated, her gaze fixed on the enormous, brilliant moon hanging in the sky. It looked like a kind, old face, pocked with craters like wise wrinkles. She imagined a workshop hidden in one of those craters, filled with tools made from meteorites and starlight. She thought of her Grandpa building his beautiful cloud-ship. Looking back at the glowing orb in the night, a wonderful idea sparked in her mind. “Grandpa,” she whispered, her voice full of awe, “The Man in the Moon… Is he building ships, too?” Grandpa smiled. “Of course, little star. Where do you think dreams come from?”

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils."

responses.text: The old oak desk had been his domain. For six months after the funeral, I couldn’t bring myself to touch it. Today, I had to. His tax files were in here somewhere. My fingers sifted through the junk drawer, a graveyard of dried-up pens and bent staples. Then, a flash of gold. I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. My breath catches. It’s not a sign of betrayal; it’s a memory. From that weekend we’d planned for our anniversary, the trip to the coast we never took. He’d bought it with a boyish grin, full of promises whispered over dinner. Then the diagnosis came, and the world shrank to hospital rooms and prescription schedules. The paper clips and pencils were the life we got. This little foil packet was the life we’d dreamed of. I clutch it in my palm, a tiny, sharp-cornered relic of a future that now belongs only to ghosts.

The Archivist’s glove closed around the strange square. I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils in the pre-Collapse office drawer. The material was alien, crinkling under my thumb. 'Item 7-Gamma,' I murmured into my recorder. 'Metallic foil, sealed. Unknown purpose.' Back at the Scriptorium, I ran it under the analyzer. The text scan was corrupted, but I pieced together fragments: 'Pleasure.' 'Protection.' 'Latex.' The Central Authority database had nothing. All records of procreation pre-Unification had been purged. We were products of the Genesis Matrix now, born of civic duty, not passion. This object was heresy. A relic from a time when intimacy was a choice, a private rebellion instead of a state-sanctioned procedure. The paper clips represented order, bureaucracy—the world we lived in now. This tiny, forbidden square represented the chaotic, beautiful world they had erased. I hid it away, a secret seed of dissent.

Cleaning out ‘Mad’ Mike’s desk was my punishment for being the last one to volunteer. The man was a whirlwind of chaos, and his desk was the eye of the storm. As I scooped out handfuls of junk, my fingers brushed against something slick. I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. I held it between my thumb and forefinger like an unholy artifact. 'Find anything good in there?' a voice asked. I spun around, fumbling the foil packet, which landed squarely on the sensible shoes of Sarah from Marketing. My crush. My mortified, beet-red, about-to-combust crush. 'Oh! Uh, that’s… not mine!' I stammered. 'It’s Mike’s. Obviously. I mean, not *obviously*, but…' She just laughed, a bright, genuine sound that cut through my panic. 'Relax,' she said, picking it up and handing it back with a wink. 'Mike’s loss, I guess. So, since you’re done with his mess, want to help me make one at the pub later?'

The cops had tossed the place, but cops are lazy. They look for guns and ledgers, not for the soul of a crime. I was looking for the soul. I popped open the desk drawer of the deceased, a tech CEO named Alistair Finch. It was the usual corporate detritus. But my fingers, trained by years of sifting through other people's filth, found a different texture. I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. Not his brand. Finch was a creature of habit, and his habits were expensive. This was a cheap, gas-station brand. A brand for a quick, sordid encounter, not a planned romantic liaison. But the important thing wasn’t the brand, it was the small nick on the corner, a tiny tear that didn't break the seal. It matched the key I’d found in the victim's pocket—a locker key. This wasn’t about sex. It was a signal. A drop. And I knew exactly which locker to check now.

This desk was the last bastion of my old life. Quitting the job was easy. Telling Mark it was over was harder. Cleaning out this drawer felt like the final boss battle. For eight years, I’d sat here, slowly dying under fluorescent lights. The drawer was a testament to that time. I swept my hand through the mess. I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. My lips twisted into a wry smile. I remember when Mark had slipped this into my bag, a hopeful gesture for a weekend getaway we’d talked about but never planned. Like our relationship, it was a promise of a future that never materialized, gathering dust among the debris of a life I was tolerating, not living. I looked at the foil packet, a symbol of a passion that had long since expired. Without a second thought, I tossed it into the trash bag along with the broken pencils and the dead-end job. It wasn’t sad. It was closure.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils."

responses.text: The drawer groaned in protest, a sound it hadn’t made since Eleanor was alive. It was her ‘everything’ drawer, a place where forgotten things went to retire. I was finally sorting through it, a task I’d put off for three years. I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. The wrapper, a vibrant, almost garish purple, felt alien in my wrinkled hand. We hadn’t… not in the last decade of her life. The cancer had taken that, along with so much else. This was from before. A relic from a weekend getaway to the coast, maybe? I remembered her laughing, packing a bag with a mischievous glint in her eye. We’d bought a box, ‘just in case,’ she'd whispered. We used one. The rest, I assumed, were long gone. But she’d kept this one, tucked away with ticket stubs and a single, dried rose petal. It wasn’t a secret or a betrayal. It was a souvenir from a time when ‘just in case’ still felt full of endless possibility. I smiled, a sad, slow curve of my lips, and slipped the little foil square into my pocket.

The desk was a graveyard of ambition. Henderson's, before they ‘streamlined his position.’ My position, now. I was excavating the top drawer, trying to make room for my own curated collection of stress balls and artisanal coffee pods. I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. ‘Magnum,’ it read. Of course. Henderson had that kind of desperate bravado. I pictured him smuggling it into the office, a secret weapon for a planned tryst with someone from marketing. Did he ever use it? Or did it just sit here, a sad, hopeful little square, while he optimized synergistically and circled back on deliverables? The expiration date was next month. A deadline he’d failed to meet, just like his Q3 targets. I imagined his hurried packing, grabbing his motivational mug but leaving this behind—a tiny monument to a work-life balance that never was. I flicked it into the bin with the rest of his detritus. The corporate cycle, I mused, consumes all. I then sprayed the drawer with disinfectant, ready to make the space my own.

Mom needed a stamp, which meant I was on a quest into the forbidden zone: the kitchen junk drawer. It was a horrifying tangle of dead batteries, twist ties, and takeout menus from places that closed in 2008. My fingers, sticky with some unknown substance, brushed against something sharp. I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. My brain short-circuited. A… condom? In my parents’ house? The wrapper was faded, the logo some brand I’d never seen in health class. I squinted at the expiration date: Best by 1998. Oh. *Oh, gross*. This thing was older than me. It was a fossil. A prehistoric reminder that my parents were once, theoretically, people who did… that. Did they buy it on their honeymoon? Did Dad carry it in his wallet for years before it found its final resting place here, next to a coupon for a free Frosty? The thought was so profoundly weird, so deeply uncool, that I dropped it back into the abyss as if it were radioactive. I decided Mom could just go to the post office herself.

Log Entry 734. Site: Suburban Dwelling, Sector 4B. The desk unit is remarkably preserved, a shrine of ‘pre-Collapse’ wood pulp and polymers. My digger-claws sift through the top receptacle, cataloging the artifacts. I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed, waterproof packet and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of metallic fasteners and graphite-core styluses. The object is small, square, and surprisingly durable. Its surface is printed with indecipherable glyphs—‘TROJAN’—likely the name of a forgotten deity or warrior clan. Inside, my scanner detects a delicate, rolled membrane of organic latex. Its purpose is a mystery. Given its placement among office tools, perhaps it was a protective sheath for a single, important stylus? Or a bladder for a micro-portion of hydration fluid, for long meetings? Some theorists suggest these were ritualistic offerings, left to ensure fertility of the stock market. Whatever its function, it speaks of a strange, hyper-specific culture; a civilization so wealthy it could afford to individually wrap and seal such a tiny, disposable item. I place it in a sterile bag, labeling it ‘Possible Tech Pouch, circa 2020s.’ The archive will be fascinated.

The target’s office was as bland as his alibi. Martin Gable, CPA. A man whose life seemed to be measured in spreadsheets and weak coffee. I was looking for anything to connect him to the data breach at OmniCorp, but his desk was a monument to meticulous boredom. Except for the top left drawer. It was a mess, a stark contrast to the rest of the sterile space. I ran a gloved finger through the clutter. I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. Interesting. A man this uptight doesn't have a chaotic drawer by accident; it's where he hides things in plain sight. This wasn’t for his wife; my surveillance confirmed that marriage was practically cryogenically frozen. This was for someone else. Someone connected to the job? An informant? A lover he was paying off with company data? The expiration date was two years from now—a recent purchase. It wasn't a forgotten relic; it was an active part of a plan. I photographed it, logged the brand and lot number. In a case this cold, a little piece of foil could be the spark that burns everything down.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils."

responses.text: I spot the shiny foil corner of a sealed condom and pull it out from beneath an avalanche of paper clips and broken pencils. It’s the top drawer of Arthur Penhaligon’s desk, the same desk where we found him slumped over three days ago, a letter opener buried in his neck. The M.E. said it was a crime of passion, but Arthur’s wife swore he was a saint. This little foil packet says otherwise. It’s a ‘Viennese Night,’ a boutique brand, sold only at one discreet little shop downtown. Not the kind of thing a happily married accountant keeps in his office drawer. The paper clips and shattered graphite are evidence of a frantic search, someone tearing the place apart looking for something. Maybe this. Or maybe what this represents: leverage. Arthur wasn't just balancing books; he was balancing a secret life. And it seems one of his accounts finally came due. This isn't just a prophylactic; it’s my first real lead, a tiny, shiny key to unlocking a very messy murder. Now I just have to find the lock it fits.

While others danced, Elara had spent the night on her knees, tracing runes into the damp earth, coaxing the fading magic of the Whisperwood into the protective wards. Her fatigue was a hollow ache behind her ribs, the feeling of her own life force poured into the land. The ancient, sentient trees of the wood were tired as well; she could feel their groaning exhaustion through the soles of her bare feet, a shared burden. They had lent her their strength, and it had cost them dearly. Waking at the snap of dawn wasn't a choice. It was a summons. The first ray of sun was the final component of the spell, the celestial lock on the gate she’d woven. She pushed herself up, joints protesting, to face the rising light. The magic was nearly complete, but it felt as though it had taken all of her with it.

Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. In Vera’s line of work, 'party' meant the chaotic aftermath at the Starlight Lounge where shipping tycoon Alistair Bastian had taken a permanent nap. She’d spent the night wading through the muck: the crocodile tears of his young wife, the tight-lipped lies of his business partner, the scent of stale gin and desperation. The tiredness was a lead weight in her bones, the kind that came from too many cigarettes and not enough answers. She figured Mrs. Bastian was tired too, though likely tired of pretending to be sad. Vera had finally crashed in her office armchair, the city’s rain-slicked symphony her only lullaby. Waking at the snap of dawn felt like a gunshot. The grey light sliced through her blinds, illuminating the dust motes dancing over her desk. It was a new day, another chance for the killer to cover their tracks. She poured a slug of bourbon into her coffee. Sleep was a luxury she couldn’t afford.

Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The party was a blur, a frantic kaleidoscope of laughing mouths, clinking glasses, and a man named Bastian whose face she couldn't quite recall. Had it even happened? The memory felt thin, like a story someone else had told her. The exhaustion was profound, a mental fog so thick she felt she was wading through it. It was the effort of keeping the world in focus, of pretending the walls of her own mind weren't trembling. The 'too' was for the other her, the one who lived behind her eyes, who was also weary from the constant, silent struggle. Then came the snap of dawn—not the gentle creep of light, but an audible crack, like a twig breaking just outside her window. It jolted her awake, heart hammering against her ribs. She was in her bed, the room still and silent. The quiet was somehow more terrifying than the phantom noise of the party. The tiredness remained, a heavy blanket smothering both the dream and the reality.

Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. Annelise had plastered on a smile for six straight hours at Kommandant Bastian’s 'party' in the heart of occupied Paris. Each dance was a risk, each sip of champagne a prayer she wouldn't say the wrong thing. Her mission: to get close enough to the Kommandant's office to photograph the maps laid out on his desk. The tiredness she felt was the crushing weight of her false identity, the constant, humming fear of discovery that vibrated just beneath her skin. Her contact, waiting in a nearby bakery, was tired too, she knew; tired of the cold, tired of the waiting, tired of the war. Annelise hadn't slept, merely collapsed into a chair in her tiny attic room, the camera’s film a hot coal against her skin. Waking at the snap of dawn was an alarm bell. The first light meant the changing of the guard, a brief window to make the exchange. The exhaustion was a foe, but freedom was the prize.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too."

responses.text: Elara clutched the railing of the sky-tram, the city’s neon glow a smear against the plexiglass. Bastian’s “party” had been a chaotic data-drop in a penthouse nightclub, the thumping bass a cover for the whisper of encrypted transfers. Now, the synth-stimulants that had kept her sharp were curdling in her veins, leaving a jittery, hollow ache. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The city below was a sprawling circuit board, its light-lanes like tired synapses firing on fumes. It never slept, but it dreamed of breaking down. She saw it in the flickering holos and the groaning of the mag-rails. A shared exhaustion. She was a courier, a ghost in its machine, and her fatigue was a reflection of its own. Her implant pinged—a confirmation of delivery. But there was no relief, only the quiet hum of the tram carrying her toward a few hours of rented sleep, a brief respite before she and the city had to pretend to be alive again.

The cobblestones were cool beneath her worn-out dancing shoes. The music from Bastian’s Solstice party still echoed faintly in her mind, a frantic, human noise trying to drown out the ancient quiet. It never could. For Lyra, the hours between the last waltz and the first bird song were when the world exhaled. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. Not just from the dancing, but from the seeing. She saw the gnarled faces in the oak trees, their bark-lips whispering laments. She saw the river, a sluggish serpent of liquid moonlight, weary from its long journey to the sea. She paused on the old stone bridge, looking up at the moon, a pale, pitted face scarred by eons of lonely vigilance. It was sinking, surrendering to the inevitable sun. She leaned against the cold stone, a silent communion passing between them. Two ancient souls, tired of the watching, waiting for the temporary blindness of the day.

Vera’s knuckles were white on the steering wheel, the vinyl cool and slick. Bastian’s “party” was a twelve-hour stakeout, watching the city’s elite trade secrets and veiled threats over champagne. Her partner, Rick, would have hated the waiting. He would have been bouncing his leg, chewing on a toothpick, a bundle of restless energy. Now, there was only the empty passenger seat and the hiss of the tires on wet asphalt. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The exhaustion was a familiar ghost, Rick’s ghost, clinging to her shoulders. It was in the gritty burn of her eyes and the tremor in her hand as she reached for the cold coffee. The city lights bled into long, distorted streaks, like weeping wounds. The whole damn city was tired of its own lies, its own rot. And she, its unwilling confessor, was tired of listening. The radio crackled to life, but she just turned it off, preferring the silence.

The front door clicked shut behind her, the muffled bass of Bastian’s party instantly silenced. Chloe breathed in the cool, clean air of 3 a.m., a stark contrast to the stuffy heat of bodies and expectations inside. She had spent hours smiling, laughing at jokes she didn’t get, and feeling utterly alien. Her feet ached, not from dancing, but from standing awkwardly in the corner. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. Her phone buzzed. It was Maya. *I’m so drained. Pretending is exhausting.* Chloe smiled, a real one this time. *Me too.* The simple admission was a lifeline. She sat on the porch steps, pulling her knees to her chest. The world was quiet, honest. The sky was beginning to soften from black to a deep, bruised purple. She wasn’t tired from the party; she was tired *of* the party. And in that shared, quiet exhaustion with her friend, she felt more connected than she had all night.

Annelise walked through the skeletal remains of Schiller Strasse, her footsteps echoing in the pre-dawn hush. Bastian’s ‘party’ had been in a cellar, the air thick with cheap tobacco, defiant jazz, and the ghosts of better times. They were all trying so hard to forget, to build a new world on the rubble of the old. But the effort was draining. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The city wore its fatigue openly. Scaffolding clung to bombed-out facades like weary limbs in splints. Piles of brick and twisted metal lay in silent testament to a violence that still hummed beneath the surface. This city, her city, was tired of mourning. Tired of the dust, the rationing, the ghosts. As the first sliver of sun crested a half-demolished cathedral, it illuminated the fresh mortar on a newly laid wall. Annelise stopped, touching the rough surface. A shared, bone-deep weariness, a mutual, unspoken promise to endure. Another day was beginning. They had to.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too."

responses.text: Elara’s new optic sensors whirred online, registering the dawn as a painful, pixelated glare through the grimy apartment window. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. But her fatigue wasn't from champagne or dancing. The 'party' had been a server raid on Bastian Corp, a chaotic cascade of code and counter-intrusion software. Her old body, slumped in a net-runner's chair miles away, was probably already being bagged by corporate security. This new shell, a cheap synth model, felt alien. Its joints ached with an unfamiliar gravity. The exhaustion was a ghost in her machine, the echo of her former self’s adrenaline crash. She had the data—Bastian’s dirty secret, encrypted on a drive now nestled in her chest cavity. But as the city's neon signs flickered out against the morning light, all she felt was the profound weariness of a soul that had died and been reborn in the space of a few hours, with no time for rest in between. She was a copy, and even copies get tired.

The first ray of sun struck the Great Oak, and Lyra felt it like a physical jolt. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The forest was also weary, its ancient boughs groaning from the strain. Bastian, the old satyr, always threw parties that bordered on cataclysm. The revelry had churned the soil, wild magic leaving scorch marks on ancient stones. Lyra had danced, yes, but her dance was one of containment, subtly weaving protective wards as tipsy gnomes stumbled into enchanted mushroom rings and pixies argued with fire sprites. Her exhaustion wasn't of the body, but of the spirit. It was the weariness of a timeless guardian watching fleeting creatures flirt with chaos. Now, as the dew-soaked leaves around her began their slow work of photosynthesis, she drew on the morning's energy, not for herself, but to begin healing the woods. The party was over, but the responsibility, like the sunrise, was eternal and unrelenting.

The alley cat screeched, a sound that sliced through the pre-dawn quiet. Detective Harding flinched, her eyes gritty from a night without sleep. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. Of course, she hadn’t 'woken up' at all. The 'party' at billionaire Bastian’s penthouse was work—a glittering affair where she’d smiled at stockbrokers and socialites, her ears straining for whispers about the missing heir. Her feet ached from heels she’d ditched hours ago, but her mind ached more, replaying conversations, searching for the lie. She’d left the glamour behind for the grime of this stakeout, watching a suspect’s brownstone. Dawn wasn't a promise of rest; it was just better lighting. As the first weak light hit the pavement, it caught something she’d missed: a small, muddy footprint near the drainpipe, too small for her current suspect. A new thread. The exhaustion receded, replaced by the familiar, cold burn of the hunt. The city never slept, and neither, it seemed, did she.

The alarm wasn't set, but her anxiety was. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. The 'too' felt redundant; tired was her default state, the heavy cloak she could never shed. The party had been a minefield of small talk and forced smiles. She’d spent hours monitoring her own breathing, her posture, the cadence of her voice, trying to appear effortlessly present while her mind screamed from a cage of self-consciousness. Bastian, a friend of a friend, had clapped her on the shoulder and said, 'You're so quiet! Loosen up!'—a comment that had cost her the last of her social energy. Now, lying in bed, the sun's arrival felt like an accusation. Sleep had been a thin, troubled veil, not a restoration. The physical exhaustion was a dull ache, but the emotional fatigue was a crushing weight on her chest, a pre-emptive exhaustion for the day she now had to face, for the performance that would have to begin all over again.

The gas lamps outside were sputtering their last as the sun bled over the London rooftops. Inside the parlor, the scent of gin and ozone lingered. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. Lady Elspeth felt the exhaustion in her very soul. Mr. Bastian’s 'party' had been a séance, a spectacle for his skeptical friends. He’d wanted proof of the beyond, and she had provided it, opening herself as a conduit. The voices had been clamorous, the ectoplasm cold and draining. One particularly nasty spirit, a hanged highwayman, had tried to cling to her. Fending him off had taken nearly everything she had. Now, with the guests gone and the first birds singing, she felt hollowed out. Her maid, asleep in her chair, was physically tired from serving drinks. Elspeth’s fatigue was different. It was the weariness of being the bridge, the toll paid for trafficking in the currency of ghosts. The spirits were at rest now, and she envied them.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too."

responses.text: The glitter from Bastian’s party clung to her skin like a second, shimmering layer of exhaustion. It had been a syn-party, a full-immersion neural event where guests shared sensory data streams instead of conversations. She’d felt the thrill of a zero-g dance floor, tasted synth-ale that fizzed with binary code, and worn the collective euphoria of a thousand minds linked in celebration. The host AI, Bastian, was tired, its core processors running hot after managing the cascade of experiences. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. It was a deep, computational fatigue. Her own wetware ached with the ghost data of other people’s joy. Dawn wasn’t a sunrise; it was the city-grid’s scheduled reboot, a wave of silent energy that washed through her apartment. Her eyelids felt heavy as the blast shields descending over the maglev tunnels. She needed to defrag, to archive the night’s memories, but the lingering echo of a shared laugh—a snippet of someone else’s code—kept her tethered to the beautiful, draining noise.

The music from Bastian’s revelry still echoed in her ears, a phantom melody played on lutes of woven starlight. They had danced in a clearing where the moss glowed with every footfall, a party thrown by the Fae that felt like a single, breathless night. But the Lord of the revel, Bastian, had grown weary of the sport, his ancient eyes betraying a deep ennui. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. When she finally stumbled from the shimmering veil of the glade, the world she knew was gone. The sapling she’d leaned against was now a gnarled, ancient oak. Her exhaustion was not of the body, but of the soul—the profound weariness of a hundred years lived in the span of a few bewitched hours. The rising sun cast long shadows that seemed unfamiliar, painting a world that had moved on without her. Her reflection in a dewdrop showed the same eyes, but now they were haunted by a century of unlived life, an unwilling immortal left behind by the fading magic.

The stale cigarette smoke of Bastian’s backroom poker game was a scent she knew she’d never wash out of her coat. He was a mid-level gangster, tired of his boss, tired of the grind, and getting sloppy. She’d spent hours laughing at his bad jokes, pouring his whiskey, listening. Every moment was a performance, a tightrope walk over a canyon of suspicion. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. Not the pleasant ache of a night well spent, but the corrosive fatigue of being someone else. Her jaw ached from the fake smile, her mind from cataloging names, dates, and overheard whispers. She hadn’t slept. Dawn snapped not with light, but with the click of the recorder in her hand as she replayed a slurred confession. The exhaustion was a heavy cloak, but underneath it, the thrill of the chase was a spark. She lit her own cigarette, the flare briefly illuminating the web of connections she’d mapped on her wall. Sleep could wait.

Lena peeled her cheek off the unfamiliar pillow, the scent of lavender and dust filling her nose. Bastian’s house was a labyrinth of sleeping bodies, casualties of a celebration that had raged until the final song. Everyone was spent, crashed out in heaps on sofas and floors. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. But as she sat up, the quiet of the morning felt different. Her tiredness wasn’t just the physical drain from dancing or the mental fog from cheap wine. It was a deeper, more profound exhaustion with the person she became at these gatherings—the loud, laughing girl who always had a witty comeback. She looked at her reflection in the dark glass of the French doors. She was tired of that stranger. The first sliver of sun cut across the lawn, and it felt less like a new beginning and more like an ultimatum. It was a quiet moment of reckoning, a silent promise to herself to stop performing and find the person who existed underneath all the noise.

At Bastian’s party, guests didn't bring wine; they brought memories. You’d cup a moment in your hands—a shimmering, tactile thought—and trade it with another guest. She had exchanged the memory of her first bicycle ride for an old sailor’s recollection of a storm in the North Sea. She’d swapped the scent of her mother’s baking for the feeling of a painter finishing their masterpiece. Bastian himself, the host, seemed drained by the end, his own memories looking pale and thin. Between Bastian’s party and waking up at the first snap of dawn, she was tired, too. Her mind was a crowded gallery of borrowed lives, a cacophony of joys and sorrows that weren’t hers. Waking was a disorienting experience. The world outside her window seemed subtly altered, colored by the perceptions of strangers. On her nightstand, where she had left her keys, sat a small, intricately carved wooden bird she had never seen before. A physical artifact of a memory she’d held for only a moment, now a permanent, beautiful weight in her own reality.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty"

responses.text: I met him in a pub in Peel, a Manx man with eyes like the sea in winter. He told me of his daughter, Ealish. She’d vanished from a glen, only to return a year and a day later, changed. She had been in a faerie kingdom, he said, a place so horrific and lovely that its beauty had scoured her mind clean of mortal imperfection. Back in our world, everything became a source of pain. The gentle curve of a seashell was a clumsy, gross parody of the spirals she’d seen in their realm. The taste of fresh bread was like ash compared to the ambrosia she’d eaten. Her mother’s loving smile seemed a twisted grimace. The world she had once cherished was now an endless gallery of crude, flawed art. The memory of fae perfection was a constant, high-pitched scream in her soul, a standard against which all reality failed. She didn't die of sadness, the old man murmured into his pint. She died of ugliness. Our ugliness. She simply couldn't stand to look at us any longer, and chose the darkness over the dim, dirty light of our world.

The Manx man I met was mending nets on the Douglas quay, his hands as gnarled as driftwood. His daughter, Fenella, had been taken, he said, for a year and a day to a faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty became a cage from which she could never truly escape. The Fae Lord returned her as promised, but it was a cruel jest. Her body was home, but her soul remained their prisoner. She’d see the shimmering spires of her prison in the reflection of a puddle. The sound of the tide was a pale echo of the music that once filled her ears, a constant, taunting reminder of what she’d lost. They were always calling to her, their whispers woven into the wind that swept off the Irish Sea. She was a ghost in her own life, tethered to two worlds and belonging to neither. He found her on the shore one morning, having walked into the waves. It wasn't to drown, he insisted, his voice cracking. It was to answer the call, to finally sever the painful link to a world she could no longer fully inhabit. In her hand, he found a single, impossibly perfect silver leaf.

He was a farmer from the island's heartland, this Manx man, and his story was as strange as the standing stones in his fields. His daughter, Kirree, had returned from her year and a day in the fae realm, but something was wrong. The place she'd been was horrific, yet so lovely that its beauty began to unmake her, weaving her into its very fabric. When she came back, the transformation continued. Her skin gained a pearlescent lustre, her eyes held the impossible colours of a nebula, and her voice harmonized with the wind. She was becoming beautiful, but it was an alien beauty, cold and distant. Her human memories were fading, replaced by an ancient, arboreal consciousness. She’d stare at her own hands, confused by their shape. One evening, she told her father she could no longer remember her mother’s face. The next morning, she was gone. He believes she didn't take her life out of sorrow, but as a final, desperate act of preservation—to die as Kirree before she became something else entirely. It was her only way to keep her soul from being completely erased by that terrible, wonderful light.

I met a Manx man near the Laxey Wheel, his face a map of grief. He told me his daughter, Orla, had made a deal. Lost in the woods, she stumbled into a faerie kingdom so horrific and lovely that its beauty demanded a price she couldn't bear to pay. For a year and a day, she lived a life of impossible splendour. She drank wine that tasted of forgotten memories and danced to music that painted pictures in the air. The Fae Queen offered her all this, but the cost was simple: she had to trade her capacity for mortal love. When Orla returned, she was a beautiful, hollow shell. She looked at her father, her mother, the dog she’d raised from a pup, and felt nothing. She could recall that she had loved them, intellectually, like a fact from a book. But the feeling itself, the warmth and the bond, was gone. The world, without that emotional anchor, became a meaningless, sterile place. The horror wasn't what she saw in the fae realm; it was the absolute emptiness she brought back inside her. She couldn't live in a world she was no longer able to love.

The Manx man I met was old, his voice thin as mist over Snaefell. He spoke of his daughter, Mona, and the faerie kingdom that stole her. It was a place of horror, he said, but it was also so lovely that its beauty was a glamour hiding a truth too monstrous to endure. For a year, she believed she was in paradise. She danced with a handsome prince in sunlit glades and ate from plates of gold. It was perfect. But on the final day, as per their laws, the glamour was lifted for a single moment before her return. The prince was a creature of fungus and clicking mandibles. The golden plates were the skulls of children, and the sweet wine was blood. The beautiful music was the symphony of their suffering. She was sent back, but the knowledge broke her. She couldn't trust anything. Was the sky truly blue? Was her father's hand really warm? Every beautiful thing was now suspect, a potential mask for some underlying nightmare. She lived in constant terror of the world, and one day, decided that not living at all was the only certain escape from the lie.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty"

responses.text: I met him in a pub in Douglas, a Manx man named Kaelen with eyes as grey as the Irish Sea. His daughter, Orla, had been taken, he said, stolen away to a place just beyond the veil. For a year and a day, she lived in a faerie kingdom of impossible splendour. He told me the horror wasn't cruelty, but intensity. Every colour was the most vibrant hue imaginable, every note of music a chord that resonated in the soul, every taste a rapture on the tongue. It was a constant, unrelenting assault of perfection. When she was returned, our world was a torment to her. The muted greens of the Manx hills were drab, birdsong was a cacophony, her mother's cooking was ash in her mouth. She described it as living in a silent, grey fog after having seen the face of God. The memory of that perfect, horrific beauty was a hook in her soul. She couldn't bear the sensory poverty of mortality, and so she sought the only true silence she could find.

The old Manx fisherman, Finn, told me his daughter Elara returned from the faerie realm a stranger. She had been gone for a year and a day, and when she came back, she was breathtaking. Her skin was flawless, her eyes held the light of distant stars, her movements were liquid grace. But it was a hollow beauty. Finn said the Fae, in their obsession with aesthetics, had sculpted her. They had smoothed away her quirks, polished off her memories, and buffed out her personality until nothing remained but a perfect, pleasing vessel. The horror of that kingdom was its artistry; it was a place where souls were raw material for masterpiece. Elara would stare into the mirror for hours, touching the face of a beautiful stranger. She had no anger, no joy, no love for her father. She was an exquisite statue with a beating heart. She took her life not out of sadness, but because she recognized she was already gone. It was just a final, tidy act of erasing the beautiful, empty shell they had sent back in her place.

He was a quiet Manx man I met mending nets on the shore of Peel. He spoke of his daughter, Nessa, and the faerie kingdom that stole her for a year and a day. He described it not as a place, but as a drug. The beauty there was a narcotic, a constant, blissful high that dissolved all thought and worry. The shimmering light, the endless music, the sweet air—it was an addiction of the soul. The inhabitants were all blissful thralls, chasing the next sensory hit. Its horror was its loveliness, a trap that offered an ecstasy so profound it made life meaningless. When they cast Nessa out, she entered a state of agonizing withdrawal. Our world, with its simple pleasures and quiet moments, was a hell of understimulation. Every breath was pain, every sight was ugly, every sound was grating. She wasn't sad; she was in a perpetual state of torment, craving a fix she could never have again. Her death was the desperate act of an addict, trying to end a craving that was consuming her from the inside out.

Liam was a Manxman, born and bred, and he believed in the old ways, the old tales of the Mooinjer Veggey. His daughter, Fionnuala, had made a deal with them, he confessed, a year and a day of her time for a miraculous catch to save his boat. She described the kingdom she was taken to as horrifyingly beautiful. It was a realm of perfect stasis. A waterfall hung in the air, its droplets frozen in their shimmering descent. A rose bloomed in perpetual, flawless perfection, never aging, never wilting. The horror was its immunity to time. Nothing ever changed, grew, or decayed. When Fionnuala returned, she was undone by the nature of our world. The sight of a browning leaf, the rust on a gate, the new lines around her father’s eyes—she saw it all as a violent, grotesque corruption. The fae realm's sterile beauty had made her allergic to life itself, with its essential, messy cycle of growth and decay. She couldn't bear to watch the world, and everyone she loved, fall apart. She chose a permanent end over the horror of impermanence.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty had rewired her soul. He said the Fae who took her did not understand human morality, only aesthetics. Their definition of 'lovely' was alien and terrifying. A beautiful melody might be woven from the captured last breaths of a dying fawn. A stunning mosaic might be crafted from the iridescent wings of living insects, pinned and writhing. The horror was not that she witnessed these things, but that she was taught to see them as beautiful. For a year and a day, her perspective was warped until she found sublime artistry in what we call cruelty. When she returned, she was infected with this fae-sight. She looked at a smiling baby and saw only the 'ugly' asymmetry of its features. She heard her father's loving words and perceived only the 'unlovely' timbre of his voice. Our world of kindness and warmth became a gallery of the grotesque to her. She couldn't escape the horror she now saw as beauty, or the beauty she now saw as horror.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty"

responses.text: I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty was absolute. He told me, his voice rough as the shingle on Peel beach, that nothing in Tir nAill, the Land of Nothing, ever changed. The apple blossoms never fell, the sunset never faded from its perfect crimson peak, the smiles of the Gentry were fixed and flawless. 'It was a beauty carved from ice,' he said, 'perfect, and perfectly dead.' When his Catriona returned, she couldn't bear our world of growth and decay. She saw the rot in a ripening pear, the coming storm in a summer sky, the skull beneath the skin of her own reflection. She’d look at a laughing child and weep for the wrinkles it would one day wear. The flawless, static beauty of that otherworld had poisoned her to the messy, vibrant, and imperfect process of living. She couldn't see a flower without seeing its grave, and so she chose to join them in the earth, seeking a final stillness our world could never offer.

I once met a Manx man whose daughter had taken her own life after a year and a day spent in some horrific faerie kingdom so lovely that its beauty was a predator. 'It wasn't just what you saw,' he explained, his knuckles white around a cold cup of tea, 'it was what it did to you.' He said the beauty there fed on you. The shimmering light of the fae city drank your memories, the celestial music consumed your emotions, the impossible colours leached the very substance of your soul. To witness it was to be hollowed out, replaced by a rapturous, ecstatic emptiness. When his daughter, Elara, was returned, she was little more than a beautiful husk. She could smile and speak, but there was no one home. The person she had been was the price of admission. She existed for months in a state of quiet, agonizing vacancy, a ghost in her own skin, haunted by a sublime beauty that had eaten her from the inside out. prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing."

responses.text: My thumb scrolls, a familiar rhythm against the glass. It’s my nightly ritual, a dive into the digital deep. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit. There's @PacificLeviathan, @Humpback_Diaries, @DeepBlueDrifters. Tonight, something feels off. A video from @Humpback_Diaries shows a whale breaching, but the pattern of water cascading from its fluke seems… intentional. Almost calligraphic. I dismiss it. An hour later, @DeepBlueDrifters posts a slow-motion clip of a blue whale feeding. The cloud of krill it engulfs briefly forms a perfect spiral, the same shape as the water from the breach. My heart quickens. I pull up a third account, @OrcaPod, and there it is: a pod surfacing in a sequence that matches the Fibonacci spiral in the krill. It’s not random. It’s a language. The drifting, feeding, and surfacing—it’s not just whale shit. It's a message being broadcast across a dozen accounts, a coordinated signal from the abyss. And for some terrifying reason, I feel like I'm the only one receiving it.

After the funeral, the world felt too loud, too sharp. Grief was a constant, high-pitched ringing in my ears. So, I retreated into the silent, blue world of my phone screen. I curated my feed until it was nothing but whales. Whales drifting in sun-dappled water, their massive bodies suspended in a state of grace. Whales feeding, their movements slow and deliberate, governed by ancient, primal needs. Whales surfacing, their exhalations misty plumes against a vast horizon. The sheer scale of them was a balm. My own pain, which felt so enormous it could swallow me whole, seemed minuscule next to a creature the size of a city bus. Their world was so simple: breathe, eat, move, exist. There was no room for the complexities of loss or regret. Watching them, I could breathe too. My therapist calls it a coping mechanism, my brother calls it 'staring at whale shit.' I call it perspective. In their immense, quiet lives, I found a silence that was finally louder than my own sorrow.

Her name is Luna. I know, it's ridiculous to name a whale I've only ever seen on Instagram, but she’s unmistakable. She has a trio of barnacles just above her right eye, like a celestial constellation. She appears on all the accounts I follow, from drone shots in Mexico to diver footage in Tonga. At first, it was a fun game of 'spot the celebrity.' But then the videos got… personal. In a clip on @WhaleWonders, she turned her eye to the camera just as my favorite song came on my playlist, holding the gaze for an unnervingly long time. A week later, on @OceanSanctuary, she breached and the splash she made perfectly mirrored the crack in my bedroom ceiling. I started talking to my phone, whispering questions to her image. Last night, I saw a new video. She was tracing patterns in the sand with her pectoral fin on the shallow seabed. I zoomed in, my breath catching in my throat. It was a crude map, a coastline I recognized from a holiday years ago. It wasn't just whale shit anymore. It was an invitation.

The official title is 'Aquatic Content Curator,' but my real job is to lie about whales. I run a network of twelve popular Instagram accounts that post serene videos of whales doing whale shit. It’s all part of the 'Blue Serenity' campaign for the mega-corporation I work for, Aeterna. We sell the illusion of a pristine ocean to build brand trust while our other divisions quietly poison it. My desk is covered in directives: 'Prioritize footage that evokes tranquility,' 'Downplay any visible skin lesions or signs of distress,' 'Geotag away from Aeterna deep-sea mining sites.' Yesterday, a new video came in from one of our drones. It was a pod of pilot whales, sluggish and disoriented, swimming in circles near our new drilling platform. The footage was flagged 'For Internal Review Only.' I stared at the screen, at the beautiful, dying animals. Then I saved the file to a personal drive. My feed is full of whale shit, but tonight, I’m going to leak something real. The contrast might just be enough to make people finally look.

“Oh my god, Brenda, you will not BELIEVE what ‘Scar-Fin’ just did,” I shrieked, nearly dropping my phone in the bathtub. My roommate yelled back from the living room, “Is that the angsty one from the Arctic feed?” “YES! He was spotted swimming with ‘Dot,’ the one from the @OrcaPod account! Remember, we thought she was still with ‘Big Guy’?” My Instagram feed is less a nature gallery and more a high-stakes reality show. I follow the lives of these whales like they’re celebrities. I have my favorites (Scar-Fin, the misunderstood bad boy), my villains (Big Guy, who is SO possessive), and my ships. The comment sections are my colosseum. I get into vicious arguments with a user named @KelpLover47 about whether Scar-Fin’s migration patterns are emotionally driven or purely instinctual. Brenda thinks I’m insane, but she just doesn’t get the nuance. This isn’t just random whale shit; it’s drama, it’s romance, it’s betrayal, all playing out on a global scale. And unlike her trashy TV shows, my stars are 50 tons and can swallow a car.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing."

responses.text: My phone is my portal to the abyss, but not in the way most people mean. When the emails pile up and the Slack notifications ping with a frantic rhythm, I escape. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It just hangs there, a cathedral of flesh and bone, a silent testament to a life lived on a different timescale. The pressure of my own life—the deadlines, the rent, the endless noise—seems to compress into a tiny, insignificant point. I watch the whale drift, its eye closed in what looks like deep meditation, and for a moment, I can breathe again. I'm not in my cramped apartment; I'm suspended in the cool, quiet depths with it, listening only to the distant song of its kin. The world can wait. The whale is drifting, and so am I.

At first, it was just a hobby, a way to decompress after long nights at the SETI institute. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit. But then I noticed the patterns. A fin slap from a blue whale off the coast of Mexico, posted by @OceanicOdyssey. Two hours later, a series of breaches from a pod of sperm whales near Japan, captured by @DeepBlueVisions. It wasn’t random. I started pulling the data, mapping the geotags, running the clicks and songs through our deep-learning algorithms. It wasn't 'playing' or 'feeding.' It was a relay. A message, passed from pod to pod, across the entire planet. The algorithm found a recipient, too—a repeating, non-terrestrial signal originating from the direction of TRAPPIST-1e. The whales weren't just singing into the void. They were in a conversation with the stars. And for the last six months, their tone has become increasingly urgent, a low, planetary hum of what I can only translate as a warning.

My therapist said my dreams were a manifestation of stress, but she hadn't seen the videos. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, and lately, that's all I dream about. I'm not just watching; I'm there, the saltwater cold on my phantom skin. Last night was different. I was swimming alongside 'Salt,' a famous humpback with a distinctive dorsal fin, when she turned her massive, ancient eye towards me. The water didn't muffle her voice; it carried it. *You see us drift,* she sang, the sound a vibration in my bones. *You call it 'playing.' But these are the old rites. The patterns we trace in the water hold the tides in place. The songs we sing keep the deepest trenches from waking.* I woke up gasping, the taste of salt on my lips. The video of Salt breaching had over a million likes. A million people had witnessed a prayer, and not one of them, except me, had understood. Now, I have to.

It started innocently enough. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit. It was calming. But the algorithm fed my fascination until it became an obsession. I knew the markings on individual whales better than I knew my own family's faces. Then I started seeing it. A flicker in the background of a feeding video—too fast, too large. A shadow in the periphery as a whale surfaced, one that didn't match any known creature. I’d freeze-frame, zoom in, convinced something was stalking them from the abyssal dark. I left frantic comments: *'CAN'T YOU SEE IT? BEHIND THE FLUKE!'* People called me a troll, a lunatic. Last night, I was watching a live stream from an ROV in the Mariana Trench. A lone sperm whale drifted into view, its clicks echoing in the crushing dark. It was peaceful. Then, from below, a shape began to ascend. It was not a whale. It was bigger. The feed went to static.

Brenda, you will not *believe* the nerve of that drone operator today. Honestly. I was in the middle of a truly sublime vertical drift—very pensive, very 'one with the ocean,' you know the vibe—and he comes in from the *side*. The side! Everyone knows my left side is my better side; it has that distinguished smattering of barnacles that really pops in the afternoon light. It completely ruined the shot. I’m trying to curate a brand here, a specific aesthetic of 'gentle giant contemplating the mysteries of the deep.' It’s what got @WhaleWatcherWeekly to feature me. All my followers know me for my serene 'whale shit,' not this amateur-hour footage. Meanwhile, Kevin the Orca is over by the San Juans doing tail flips for a boat full of tourists like a common street performer. It’s so tacky. He's all about cheap engagement, but I'm building a legacy. Now if you'll excuse me, the light is hitting the kelp forest just right and I feel a truly profound breach coming on. This one's going viral, I can feel it.

It started as a relaxing hobby. Hidden in the clicks and whistles were patterned sequences, too regular for nature. It’s a code. I don’t know who is sending it, or why they’re using these beautiful, impossible videos as a broadcast channel. But I’m listening. The first time it happened, I’d been watching a video of a blue whale. The camera was so close you could see the universe of barnacles on its skin. After watching a pod of sperm whales sleeping vertically, I woke to find a fine layer of black, volcanic sand on my windowsill. The city traffic outside my window began to sound less like cars and more like the low, mournful songs I heard on @CetaceanCall. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, but it feels less like I’m watching them and more like they are watching me. Last night, I saw a shimmer in the corner of my eye, the ghost of a fluke disappearing into the plaster of my wall. I’m not scared. It feels like the tide is coming in, and my small life is finally becoming part of a larger ocean.

My guidance counselor asked about my passions. My friends are into makeup tutorials and gaming streams. I told her the truth: 'I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing.' She gave me a weird look. But she doesn’t see what I see. When I watch a fin whale lunge-feeding, I don’t just see a big mouth. I see the mechanics of its ventral pleats expanding, a miracle of biological engineering. I see social structures in the way a pod of orcas cooperates to hunt. I’ve learned to identify individuals by their dorsal fins and fluke patterns from accounts like @OceanOdyssey and @FlukeID. I have notebooks filled with observations, screenshots annotated with questions about migration patterns and vocalizations. This isn’t a passive hobby; it’s my education. These short clips of 'whale shit' are my primary sources, my window into a world I plan to spend my life studying. My passion isn't Instagram; it's the vast, blue wilderness it shows me.

From my van parked across the street, I watch the target, Subject 42. He’s predictable. Every evening after work, he sits in the dark, illuminated only by his phone. My console mirrors his screen. I expected social media, news, dating apps. I did not expect this. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit—that’s the entirety of his digital life. He scrolls for hours. He doesn’t 'like' or comment; he just watches. He sees a minke whale breach, and the tension in his shoulders, so evident when he walked in, dissolves. He watches a gray whale nurse its calf, and he lets out a slow, quiet breath. Our psychological profile suggested a man isolated and yearning for connection. We thought the 'connection' would be human. We were wrong. His yearning is deeper, wider. He's not looking for a person; he's looking for the abyss. This changes our approach. We don’t need to offer him community. We need to offer him the tide.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing."

responses.text: My feed is an endless blue. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It’s my zen. But last week, I noticed something odd. An account called @DeepBlueDrifters posted a video of a humpback’s fluke, tagged #OceanLife. Simple enough. But the pattern of water dripping from the fluke… it looked like Morse code. I dismissed it. Then @CetaceanWonders posted a clip of a blue whale’s eye, and the slow, deliberate blinks matched a binary sequence I’d seen in a cryptography forum. It’s happening across all the accounts. The breaching patterns, the clicks in the audio, the angles of their pectoral fins. I’m not just watching whales drift anymore. I’m watching them talk. They’re coordinating something, using our insatiable appetite for serene content to pass messages right under our noses. And I, some random doomscroller, am the only one who seems to have cracked the code. The question is, what are they planning, and who are they talking to?

The emergency room is a symphony of controlled chaos—beeps, shouts, the squeak of shoes on linoleum, the constant hum of anxiety. During my thirty-minute break, hiding in a sterile supply closet, I find my sanctuary. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit. There’s no drama, no emergency. Just a forty-ton leviathan drifting in a sun-dappled abyss, utterly unbothered. I watch a fin whale filter-feeding, its movements slow, ancient, and purposeful. It has one job: to eat, to move, to exist. The sheer scale of it recalibrates me. My patient’s crisis, the hospital politics, my exhaustion—it all shrinks against the backdrop of this creature’s immense, quiet life. The video ends. I take a deep breath, the scent of antiseptic filling my lungs. The alarms are still screaming out in the hallway, but for a moment, I was somewhere else, somewhere deep and calm and silent. It’s enough. I can go back out there now. I put my phone away and step back into the noise.

It started as a simple coping mechanism. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit. The calm is infectious. But then it became… more. When I watch a pod of orcas playing, a phantom joy bubbles in my chest, light and effervescent. When I see a close-up of a humpback mother nudging her calf, a fierce, protective love I’ve never known floods my senses, bringing tears to my eyes. It’s not just empathy; I feel it in my bones, a strange, somatic echo across the digital divide. This morning, a new video appeared. It was a minke whale, horribly tangled in ghost netting, its movements frantic and terrified. The moment I saw it, a sharp, searing pain shot through my own shoulder, and I felt the rough scrape of phantom ropes on my skin. A desperate, breathless panic seized me. The caption gave the location: a remote bay in Nova Scotia. It’s a twelve-hour drive. I’m already packing my car. I don’t know what I’ll do when I get there, but I know I can’t just watch anymore.

My nightly ritual is scrolling through whale videos. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit. It’s supposed to be calming. Lately, it isn’t. At first, it was things I could dismiss. A shadow in the deep that seemed to move against the current. A shape in a pod of sperm whales that was too long, too serpentine. The accounts, with names like @WhaleJoy and @OceanPeace, kept the captions cheerful. ‘Look at this majestic giant!’ But the whales’ behavior seemed off. The ‘drifting’ looked like exhaustion. The ‘playing’ looked like panicked fleeing. Last night’s video was the worst. A close-up of a blue whale’s flank, the camera panning slowly. For a split second, reflected in the water on its skin, I saw the videographer. It wasn’t a diver or a drone. It was a single, immense, unblinking eye, larger than the whale itself. The caption read, ‘Making a new friend in the deep! #BFFs’. My blood ran cold. We aren’t the only ones watching the whales. We’re just watching the bait.

My name is Barnaby, and I am a fin whale of some renown on the ‘Gram. My agent, a hyperactive bottlenose dolphin named Click, says my brand is ‘serene majesty.’ It’s exhausting. Humans, I’m told, follow my account because they love watching me do ‘whale shit.’ If they only knew. This morning’s shoot was a nightmare. ‘Okay, Barnaby, give me a deep, soulful drift,’ Click squeaked through the water. ‘But look… lonely. Existentially lonely. But also peaceful.’ I just wanted to scratch an itch on a passing coral reef. Yesterday, it was ‘contemplative feeding.’ I had to strain krill while looking like I was pondering the mysteries of the universe. I wasn’t. I was thinking about how much krill I had to eat to maintain this ridiculous physique. My real passions—competitive breaching, composing mournful ballads about squid that got away, avant-garde bubble-net art—are deemed ‘off-brand.’ They just want the placid, screensaver-friendly content. I swear, if Click asks me to do one more ‘playful fluke splash for the Boomerang feature,’ I’m going to go find a container ship to photobomb.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing."

responses.text: My screen is a tiny, glowing portal to the abyssal plain. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. For me, it’s a form of therapy. My apartment is small, the city is loud, and my job is a frantic scramble of deadlines and demands. But for a few minutes, I can watch a humpback mother nudge her calf towards the surface, the water distorting the light into a shimmering halo around them. I can see the silent, slow-motion ballet of a blue whale, a creature longer than my entire apartment building, simply existing. There are no captions trying to sell me something, no influencers posing. It’s just the deep, quiet blue and the profound, unbothered peace of an animal that measures its life in decades and migration patterns. It’s a reminder of a world that operates on a scale I can’t comprehend, and in that vastness, my own anxieties feel reassuringly small and temporary. The gentle drift of a fin whale is my meditation.

The official story is that the oceans boiled a century ago. The Leviathans are gone, existing only as skeletal curiosities in museums. But I know better. I’m a data archaeologist, and my specialty is sifting through the digital ghosts of the 21st century. My secret obsession is a collection of defunct Instagram accounts I salvaged from a corrupted server: @WhaleVids, @DeepBlueDaily, @OrcaPod. The bio descriptions are unrecoverable, but the media remains. I follow these ghost accounts, watching endless loops of whales doing whale shit. A fin whale surfaces, its blowhole misting the pixels. A pod of orcas plays in a kelp forest. These aren't just records; they feel like memories. Sometimes, late at night in my sterile data-bunker, I’ll see a new post. A grainy video of a dark shape drifting in bioluminescent plankton. It’s impossible. The accounts are dead. Yet, something is out there, in the toxic depths, and it’s using the old network to whisper, ‘We are still here.’

It started as a way to calm my anxiety. My therapist suggested I find something soothing to focus on, so I started following Instagram accounts dedicated to whales. Just simple videos of them doing whale shit: a massive blue drifting in the sun-dappled water, a pod of orcas chasing a current. It worked, for a while. The deep blue was a balm. Then, the algorithm got weirdly specific. The videos started to feel… directed. A close-up of a whale’s eye, ancient and intelligent, would linger just a second too long. I’d have a nightmare about drowning, and the next morning my feed would show a video of a whale sinking slowly into the blackness. The calming whale songs I played to sleep now sounded like the groaning foundations of my old apartment building. Last night, I watched a video of a humpback breaching. As it crashed back into the water, my reflection in the dark screen didn’t flinch. It just smiled, and for a terrifying moment, I felt the crushing, cold weight of the ocean inside my own chest.

Dr. Aris Thorne followed dozens of whale-watching accounts for his doctoral research, dismissing them as amateurish but occasionally useful. The videos were mostly the same: blurry footage of whales doing whale shit. But one account, @Eye_in_the_Deep, was different. The cinematography was impossible. The camera would glide alongside a pod of sperm whales, dip under a pectoral fin, and hover inches from a placid eye, all without the tell-tale bubble trail of a scuba diver or the whir of a drone. There was no boat, no human presence at all. One day, Aris plotted the GPS data from his own tagged orca, ‘Luna,’ against the account’s posts. A video of an orca chasing a stingray was uploaded two minutes after Luna had done that exact thing, thousands of miles from any known human. He stared at the screen, at a new video of Luna looking directly into the ‘camera.’ Aris realized with a jolt of electrifying fear and wonder: the whales weren't the subjects of the videos. They were the filmmakers. They were showing him their world, and he was only just beginning to understand the message.

My grandfather doesn’t ‘get’ the internet, but he gets whales. His world has become very small since Grandma died: his chair, the television, the window overlooking the bird feeder. So, I set him up with a tablet and followed a dozen accounts that only post videos of whales doing whale shit. I thought he’d be bored, but it’s become his ritual. He calls me to give me updates. ‘The big fella with the barnacles on his nose is back,’ he’ll say, describing a humpback from @GentleGiants. ‘He was just floating there today, having a think.’ He doesn’t see random animals; he sees characters. There's the 'show-off' orca who always breaches near the boats, and the 'shy one,' a minke whale that only appears as a fleeting shadow. These short, silent clips of creatures living their immense, mysterious lives have opened his world back up. He’s not just watching a screen; he’s whale-watching from his armchair in Ohio, connected to something vast and wild and beautifully alive. For the first time in years, his world feels big again.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing."

responses.text: I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It’s my zen, my escape from the concrete grid of the city. But last week, I noticed something odd. A video from @AbyssWatcher showed a humpback near Tonga. The same day, @PacificBlue posted a clip of what looked like the same whale—same unique fluke scar—off the coast of Mexico. Impossible. I started cross-referencing. The whale, my impossible whale, was appearing across the globe, simultaneously. It wasn’t a glitch. It was a message. Last night, I saw a new video from a local drone account. It was him, my whale, breaching just beyond the pier a mile from my apartment. The caption read, ‘Look who came to visit!’ He wasn’t just doing whale shit anymore. He was doing something just for me. He was waiting.

My thumb scrolls, a mindless metronome against the screen. Humpback, fin, orca, repeat. I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. It’s supposed to be calming, an oceanic balm for my frayed millennial nerves. But lately, the calm is gone. The close-ups are too close. In the deep-sea gloom behind a feeding blue whale, I saw a shape move. Something with too many angles. In another video, the audio of a pod of pilot whales seemed to carry a sub-harmonic, a discordant thrum that made my teeth ache. They aren’t just ‘drifting.’ They’re patrolling. They’re a living wall, a sonar fence against something ancient in the abyss. We see them as gentle giants, but we’re wrong. They’re prison guards, and through these tiny phone screens, I think I’m beginning to see the prisoner stir.

My therapist suggested it. ‘Find something calming, Elara. Something vast.’ So now, I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. My life is a series of deadlines and notifications, a shrieking digital cacophony. But a 30-second clip of a sperm whale sleeping vertically in the dark, motionless and profound, silences it all. The sheer, unbothered weight of it. It doesn’t care about my quarterly reports or the passive-aggressive email from my boss. It just *is*. Last Tuesday, during a panic attack so bad I couldn’t breathe, I fumbled for my phone. A new post: a mother humpback nudging her calf to the surface. I watched it loop, matching my breath to the slow, majestic rise and fall. In, out. Surface, dive. The vastness held me. The whale saved me.

I follow a bunch of Instagram accounts that are just pictures and the occasional close-up video of whales doing whale shit, like drifting or feeding or surfacing or playing. For me, it’s not about nature; it’s about data. I’m a linguistics student, and I’ve been running the audio from these videos through a deep-learning analysis program. For months, nothing but clicks, moans, and whistles. But then, I isolated the patterns. It wasn’t random. I found syntax, repetition, a complex call-and-response system hidden beneath the noise. They’re talking. Not just to each other, but about something specific. The models keep flagging one recurring sequence, a sound that corresponds with seismic data from the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. It’s not a song about food or migration. It’s more precise. It’s an engineering schematic. A set of instructions. They aren’t just living in the ocean; they’re maintaining it. And something is breaking.

‘Okay Bartholomew, on my mark, give me majestic!’ Chad screams from the drone controller. I sigh and heave another bucket of chum over the side of the boat. My internship is with @WhaleVibez, one of those accounts I used to follow, the ones with pictures and close-up videos of whales doing whale shit. I thought it would be a spiritual journey. It’s not. Bartholomew, the 40-ton humpback, is less a majestic sea titan and more a lazy dog who only performs for snacks. The ‘serene drift’ that got 2 million views was him in a food coma. The ‘playful breach’ was a tantrum because we ran out of his favorite herring. Chad is currently trying to get Bartholomew to pose with a waterproof, algae-based, vegan protein bar for a sponsorship deal. ‘He’s not feeling it, Chad!’ I yell over the wind. ‘He looks sad!’ Chad scoffs. ‘Slap an inspirational quote on it. ‘The ocean’s depths hold no sorrow that its surface cannot heal.’ Boom. Content.’

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "It was more than possible."

responses.text: Dr. Aris Thorne stared at the telemetry, his coffee growing cold. For weeks, the anomaly designated XO-27b had defied classification. It wasn't a star, nor a nebula, nor a black hole. It was a void that didn't just absorb light, but seemed to actively… erase it. His team had theorized it could be a stable wormhole, a gateway to another universe. A thrilling, academic possibility. But the new data was different. Patterns were emerging in the chaotic energy signatures at the void's edge—complex, non-random, and responsive. When they broadcast a simple prime number sequence, the patterns shifted, mimicking the sequence back at them across 500 light-years. Someone, or something, was on the other side. The idea of making first contact had driven his entire career, a lifelong dream. But looking at the data that suggested the 'void' was now dilating, focusing on them like a vast, cosmic eye, Aris felt a primal dread. For humanity to no longer be alone in the universe? It was more than possible; it was a terrifying, imminent certainty.

The villagers called it star-iron, a substance of myth. Old Man Hemlock spun tales of swords that could cut through stone, forged from metal that fell from the heavens. Finn, the blacksmith’s apprentice, had always considered them just stories. Then came the night of the twin-tailed comet, and the earth-shaking crash in the Whispering Woods. He found the meteorite in a smoldering crater, a lump of pitted, strangely warm metal that hummed with a low energy. For a month, he toiled in secret. His master’s forge could barely heat the ore, and his strongest hammer blows only chipped the surface. He was a fool, chasing a fairytale. But then, following a half-remembered instruction from Hemlock’s tale, he quenched the glowing metal not in water, but in fresh morning dew collected under a full moon. The metal hissed, and for the first time, it became pliable. It folded under his hammer, revealing layers of shimmering, otherworldly light. To create a blade from the heart of a fallen star? It was more than possible; it was taking shape in his very hands, a legend reborn.

Detective Miles Corbin hated cases like this. The ‘Phantom’ was a ghost, a specter who stole priceless artifacts from sealed rooms without leaving a trace. No forced entry, no tripped sensors, no surveillance footage. His superiors were pushing the 'inside job' angle, but Corbin knew it was something else. At each crime scene, he felt it: a faint, static charge in the air, a subtle wrongness that made the hairs on his arm stand up. He started digging into fringe science, theoretical physics, concepts he’d dismissed as science fiction. Quantum tunneling. The idea that subatomic particles could pass through solid barriers. Could a person do it? It was insane. Yet, as he stood before the latest crime scene—a priceless Fabergé egg vanished from a solid glass case inside a locked museum—he saw no other way. There were no seams, no hidden latches, no conceivable trick. The thief hadn't broken in. They had simply walked through the wall. It defied all logic, but as he stared at the impossible scene, Corbin had to admit it. It was more than possible; it was the only answer.

Nico, Leonardo da Vinci's youngest apprentice, was tasked with cleaning the workshop's forgotten corners.
